update.description:
* first stage of drift included in example solution

* first version of working drift example solution

* The example works in open spaces for now where the robot is able to turn around in its own position without its arms hitting the walls/etc.

* Try to call service ` /servicesim/drift`  when the dropoff state has been started
update.title: Drift example solution

content.raw:
+1

Though I still think it should be set to False at the beginning of the function and not the end, otherwise any piece of code changing this variable after init and before this function is called will cause this to use random data.

Quick note: this variable has no utility outside this function so it should be a local variable (in the function's scope), this would allow you to not allocate memory for it for the entire lifetime of the class' instance and prevent unexpected effect like the one I mentioned above
content.html:
+1

Though I still think it should be set to False at the beginning of the function and not the end, otherwise any piece of code changing this variable after init and before this function is called will cause this to use random data.

Quick note: this variable has no utility outside this function so it should be a local variable (in the function's scope), this would allow you to not allocate memory for it for the entire lifetime of the class' instance and prevent unexpected effect like the one I mentioned above

content.raw: Sounds good. Looks like get_time() is just calling `Time.now().to_sec()`: https://github.com/ros/ros_comm/blob/2c8a3f65628d0362d97c29d333d5669b2c7803a6/clients/rospy/src/rospy/rostime.py#L201-L207
content.html: Sounds good. Looks like get_time() is just calling Time.now().to_sec(): https://github.com/ros/ros_comm/blob/2c8a3f65628d0362d97c29d333d5669b2c7803a6/clients/rospy/src/rospy/rostime.py#L201-L207

content.raw:
I was using rospy.get_time() to get time in (float) secs, 
It seems all the same, See the console output when i try to print them: 

>>> print rospy.Time.now()

1522172887354388952

>>> print rospy.get_time()

1522172888.39

>>> print rospy.get_rostime()

1522172891098419904
content.html:
I was using rospy.get_time() to get time in (float) secs, It seems all the same, See the console output when i try to print them:

print rospy.Time.now()

1522172887354388952

print rospy.get_time()

1522172888.39

print rospy.get_rostime()

1522172891098419904

content.raw: if the transform is not found this variable has not been created so cannot be checked in a condition. `self.transform_flag=False` should be placed at the beginning of the function and not at the end
content.html: if the transform is not found this variable has not been created so cannot be checked in a condition. self.transform_flag=False should be placed at the beginning of the function and not at the end

content.raw: this should return "something". Either an empty goal or `None`
content.html: this should return "something". Either an empty goal or None

content.raw: is this rate used anywhere ?
content.html: is this rate used anywhere ?

content.raw:
What is the reason for changing `rospy.Time.now()` to `rospy.get_time()` here?
(I should double check but) I think that this will give you system time and not ROS time so this will behave differently based on the real time factor. So I suggest going back to using now() or use `rospy.get_rostime()`
content.html: What is the reason for changing rospy.Time.now() to rospy.get_time() here? (I should double check but) I think that this will give you system time and not ROS time so this will behave differently based on the real time factor. So I suggest going back to using now() or use rospy.get_rostime()

content.raw: this should also be a `build_depend` as the dependency is needed at build time to generate the messages. It should also be listed in the `catkin_package` call as a `CATKIN_DEPEND`
content.html: this should also be a build_depend as the dependency is needed at build time to generate the messages. It should also be listed in the catkin_package call as a CATKIN_DEPEND

content.raw: @chapulina, I've made some changes after discussing with Mikael, to resolve the issue where the robot misses completely to repickup the guest because the last rfid data has the guest name in it and the rfid data is not updated unless some human is in the range where the robot realizes the guest is lost. I've also resolved the changes @mikaelarguedas  suggested previously. Please check and merge the changes if it works as expected. Thanks!
content.html: @chapulina, I've made some changes after discussing with Mikael, to resolve the issue where the robot misses completely to repickup the guest because the last rfid data has the guest name in it and the rfid data is not updated unless some human is in the range where the robot realizes the guest is lost. I've also resolved the changes @mikaelarguedas suggested previously. Please check and merge the changes if it works as expected. Thanks!

content.raw: On Gazebo / Ign we use 80, but on ServiceSim we're not adhering to any specific style as long as things look reasonably clean. I agree that below 120 should be good enough.
content.html: On Gazebo / Ign we use 80, but on ServiceSim we're not adhering to any specific style as long as things look reasonably clean. I agree that below 120 should be good enough.

content.raw:
Line length is more subjective as most people agree that now the 80 character limits due to antique terminals doesnt apply anymore. I use 100 characters for the code I write as it is the style for ROS2. In ROS1 in general people stick with 120 (http://wiki.ros.org/CppStyleGuide#Line_length).  I don't know what convention Gazebo follows in general.
So I'd say if anything is longer than 120 let's split it, otherwise I don't this it's worth spending time splitting them
content.html: Line length is more subjective as most people agree that now the 80 character limits due to antique terminals doesnt apply anymore. I use 100 characters for the code I write as it is the style for ROS2. In ROS1 in general people stick with 120 (http://wiki.ros.org/CppStyleGuide#Line_length). I don't know what convention Gazebo follows in general. So I'd say if anything is longer than 120 let's split it, otherwise I don't this it's worth spending time splitting them

content.raw: Nit: build depends are commonly listed before the exec depends (after the buildtool depends) so that it's easy at a glance to know what is needed to build a package
content.html: Nit: build depends are commonly listed before the exec depends (after the buildtool depends) so that it's easy at a glance to know what is needed to build a package

content.raw: Nit: this should be in the list of exec depends and placed according to alphabetical order
